Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Availability of Employment Opportunities and Recidivism Outcomes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The U.S. prison population continues to grow and devising policies to reduce recidivism and criminal justice expenditures is now a major bi-partisan priority. Policy makers are focusing on improving employment outcomes for former prisoners as a way of reducing recidivism and generating tax revenue. We propose a detailed study of the relationship between employment timing and recidivism. We focus on whether employment that occurs rapidly after release (within the first three months) is more effective in reducing the likelihood of recidivism than remaining unemployed or taking a longer period of time to find a job. Our project also examines the characteristics of the broader economy such as the local unemployment rate and the kinds of job openings available in the local labor market, characteristics often associated with rapid and successful job search. The analysis will employ appropriate statistical techniques and is based on recidivism data collected from the Ohio Department of Rehabilitation and Correction (ODRC) and employment data from the Ohio Department of Job and Family Services (ODJFS).

To address our research question, we gather and construct a unique set of data and perform an analysis of recidivism outcomes. Our data task involves gathering administrative records including Unemployment Insurance (UI), Employer Enterprise (EE) and Adult Workforce Education (AWE) data created by the Ohio Department of Job and Family Services (ODJFS), and matching them with the records of four representative samples of Ohio state prisoners (previously gathered, geocoded, and merged with census tract/block group data) from the Ohio Department of Rehabilitation and Correction (ODRC). Additional records pertaining to mental health status, verbal ability, and work assignment in prison available from ODRC will be gathered and merged to supplement pre-existing collections. Our analysis task involves analyzing recidivism outcomes (parole violations, arrest, parole revocation, and re-incarceration for new crime) with careful scrutiny of the independent and joint influences of (a) the timing and quality of employment experiences and (b) local employment opportunity (unemployment, presence of low skill employment opportunity) and (c) concentrated disadvantage in the neighborhood (block group, tract, county). The overall goal is to assess the unique contribution that timing of employment plays in reducing prison recidivism, contributing to the reintegration of ex-offenders into the wider society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the period of the award, we were able to collect Unemployment Insurance (UI) data from the Ohio Department of Job and Family Services and merge it with recidivism data collected from the Ohio Department of Rehabilitation and Correction.

Thus far we completed one paper that examines a core question at the heart of Sampson and Laub's (1993) age-graded theory of informal social control -- why does a transition into employment become a turning point for some ex-prisoners, but not for others? We found that a substantial number of individuals that are employed in the legal labor market also participate in drug selling. When that group is partitioned from those who work legally but don’t sell drugs, we find that employment produces a sizable reduction in the likelihood of street crime. Those that sell drugs during the same periods in which they work have greater involvement in street crime than the unblended group, and also relative to those that sell drugs exclusively and those who neither sell drugs or work. We plan to follow up on this finding and recontact the study participants to determine how the patterns change over time.

We also proposed a detailed study of the relationship between employment and recidivism (returning to prison due to being convicted of a new felony). The focus is on employment patterns immediately following release, such as within the first three months, and whether immediate employment is most effective in reducing the likelihood of recidivism. It is also likely that the chances of finding employment depend on characteristics of the returning citizen (i.e., ex-prisoner) such as their education and prior employment patterns, and also the broader economy to include the unemployment rate and the kinds of job openings available in the local labor market.

 

The results are very promising and are being written up into a paper intended for journal submission. The results indicate that job stability and higher wages in the period following release from prison are associated with a reduced likelihood of returning to prison. The findings support the view that more attention should be directed towards encouraging, preparing, and assisting inmates find legal work upon release from prison. Much research remains to be done with this very valuable data set.
